sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Dyspareunia (Moderate to Severe), Due to vulvar and vaginal atrophy associated with menopause: 60 mg ORALLY once daily with food for the shortest duration necessary; in women with a uterus, consider concomitant progestin therapy

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: not indicated for use in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: dosage adjustment not required
  • hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh class A) or moderate (Child-Pugh class B): dosage adjustment not required; do not use in patients with severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh class C)

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Dyspareunia (Moderate to Severe), Due to vulvar and vaginal atrophy associated with menopause

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Ospemifene is an estrogen agonist/antagonist with tissue selective effects. In the endometrium, ospemifene has estrogen agonistic effects. There is an increased risk of endometrial cancer in a woman with a uterus who uses unopposed estrogens. Adding a progestin to estrogen therapy reduces the risk of endometrial hyperplasia, which may be a precursor to endometrial cancer. Estrogen-alone therapy has an increased risk of stroke and DVT. Ospemifene 60 mg/day had cerebral thromboembolic and hemorrhagic stroke incidences of 0.72 and 1.45 per 1000 women, respectively, vs 1.04 and 0 per 1000 women in placebo. The incidence of DVT for ospemifene 60 mg/day is 1.45 per 1000 women vs 1.04 per 1000 women in placebo.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Arterial thromboembolic disease (eg, stroke and myocardial infarctions), active or history
  • DVT or pulmonary embolism, active or history
  • Estrogen-dependent neoplasia, known or suspected
  • Genital bleeding, abnormal and undiagnosed
  • Hypersensitivity (eg, angioedema, pruritus, rash, urticaria) to ospemifene or any component
  • Pregnancy should be avoided; known teratogen

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Hemorrhagic and thromboembolic stroke has occurred, with increased risk in postmenopausal women treated with unopposed estrogen; discontinue use if stroke occurs or is suspected
  • -- DVT has occurred, with increased risk in postmenopausal women treated with unopposed estrogen; discontinue use if VTE occurs
  • -- Endometrial cancer may occur as increased risk exists in use of unopposed estrogen in postmenopausal women; ospemifene is an estrogen agonist/antagonist with tissue selective effects
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Use in patients with breast cancer (known, suspected, or history) is not recommended
  • Hematologic:
  • -- DVT has been reported; discontinue use if suspected
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Use in patients with severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class C) is not recommended
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Hemorrhagic or thromboembolic stroke has been reported; discontinue use if suspected
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Endometrial cancer may occur as increased risk exists in use of unopposed estrogen in postmenopausal women
  • Other:
  • -- Patients undergoing periods of prolonged immobilization (eg, postsurgical recovery) have an increased risk of VTE; discontinue use at least 4 weeks before anticipated immobilization period
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Use with estrogens or other estrogen agonist/antagonists is not recommended
  • -- Use with fluconazole is not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ospemifene is a tissue selective, estrogen agonist and antagonist, which acts by binding to estrogen receptors, resulting in activation of estrogenic pathways in some tissues and blockage of estrogenic pathways in other tissues.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 2 hours (range, 1 to 8 hours)
  • Effects of food (high-fat/high-calorie meal, 860 cal): AUC, 1.7-fold increase; Bioavailability, 2- to 3-fold increase; Cmax, 2.3-fold increase; Tmax, 2.5 hours

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding, serum proteins: greater than 99%
  • Vd: 448 L

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Liver: primary
  • 4-hydroxyosphemifene: unknown
  • Inhibitor (weak, in order of decreasing potency) of CYP2B6, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, CYP2C8, CYP2D6, and CYP3A4
  • Substrate of CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 75%
  • Renal: 7%; less than 0.2% unchanged
  • Total body clearance: 9.16 L/hr

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in signs and symptoms of menopause-associated severe dyspareunia is indicative of efficacy
  • diagnostic measures including directed or random endometrial sampling; to rule out malignancy in cases of undiagnosed, persistent/recurrent abnormal genital bleeding (contraindication for use)

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to promptly report unusual vaginal bleeding, or symptoms of DVT or VTE (eg, pulmonary embolism or stroke).
  • Drug may cause hot flashes or flushing, vaginal discharge, muscle spasms, genital discharge, and hyperhidrosis.
  • Instruct patient to take once daily with food.
  • Instruct patient to consult a healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including nonprescription medications, vitamins, and herbal supplements) to avoid potential drug interactions.
